content:
Let F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B be a functor, and let ImFIm FImF be the smallest subcategory of BBB that contains F(A)F(A)F(A).

I think we can view ImFIm FImF as "information about AAA observed by BBB through FFF". From this perspective some functors will be more informative than others, I think. For example, if ImGIm GImG is a proper subcategory of ImFIm FImF, we might say that GGG is a less informative observation of AAA in BBB. Perhaps similarly, we might say that FFF is no more informative than GGG if there is a functor H:B→BH: B \to BH:B→B so that H∘G=FH \circ G = FH∘G=F.

Consider now the collection of all subcategories of BBB of the form ImFIm FImF for some functor F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B. Does this collection have some natural kind of structure (perhaps ordered with respect to "informativeness")? Intuitively it feels like it should reflect in some way the structure of the subobjects of AAA.

If AAA is any subcategory of BBB, there is a functor F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B that is the identity on objects of AAA and morphisms of AAA: this is usually called "the inclusion of AAA in BBB".

Note that A=ImFA = Im FA=ImF, i.e. AAA is the smallest subcategory of BBB that contains F(A)F(A)F(A) (=A= A=A).

So when you say

Consider now the collection of all subcategories of BBB of the form ImFIm FImF for some functor F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B.

this is equivalent to saying "consider now the collection of all subcategories of BBB". I think this is a simpler way to think about things.

Does this collection have some natural kind of structure (perhaps ordered with respect to "informativeness")?

It is partially ordered by inclusion: that is, we can say A≤A′A \le A'A≤A′ if every object (resp. morphism) of AAA is an object (resp. morphism) of A′A'A′, and this relation ≤\le≤ is a partial order.

Thanks @John Baez for your thoughts above. It makes sense that the subcategories of BBB are ordered by inclusion.
However, I am actually primarily interested in the case where AAA is fixed (maybe I didn't convey that very clearly, though). Then, it often isn't the case that we can express any subcategory of BBB as the smallest subcategory containing the image of some functor FFF mapping from AAA.
For example, consider two sets AAA and BBB as discrete categories, with a functor F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B being a function between them. Then if AAA has fewer elements than BBB, then we can't express every subcategory (subset) of BBB as the image of some function F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B.
I suppose, however, that the resulting subcategories are still ordered by inclusion.

It can also be interesting to think about what happens as BBB varies, but AAA is held fixed. For example, consider the case where AAA and BBB are sets viewed as discrete categories, and BBB has a single element. Then we only have one functor from AAA to BBB - the functor that sends everything to a single object. The fact that this image subcategory of BBB exists tells us that AAA has at least one element, but not anything more. If BBB has two elements, then functors into BBB can start to detect a bit more about AAA. Although, it is interesting to note here that not all functors from AAA in this case are equally informative. I suppose an ordering on these can be inherited from the ordering by inclusion of the subcategories they induce.

For context, I was learning a bit about reflective subcategories. The "reflection" in a subcategory of an object I think corresponds to the one that detects as much as possible in that subcategory about the object being reflected.

This is the diagram I have in mind motivating this line of thought, although the notation used here annoyingly swaps AAA and BBB compared to what I said above:
reflection

(image from "Abstract and Concrete Categories", here A\mathbf{A}A is a subcategory of B\mathbf{B}B, also AAA is an object of A\mathbf{A}A and BBB an object of B\mathbf{B}B)

David Egolf said:

Thanks John Baez for your thoughts above. It makes sense that the subcategories of BBB are ordered by inclusion. However, I am actually primarily interested in the case where AAA is fixed (maybe I didn't convey that very clearly, though).

Oh, wow! Okay, that's more subtle.

Although, it is interesting to note here that not all functors from AAA in this case are equally informative.

I wish you'd give a formal definition of what you mean here by "equally informative". Maybe you have some intuition for it but are still struggling to formalize it. But it's a bit hard for mathematicians to help until you do.

Here's a simple and interesting case to think about.

Suppose BBB is the category whose objects are natural numbers, with a single morphism from mmm to nnn if m≤nm \le nm≤n and none otherwise. Category theorists might draw this as

∙→∙→∙→⋯ \bullet \to \bullet \to \bullet \to \cdots ∙→∙→∙→⋯

Then taking A=BA = BA=B, there are infinitely many functors F:A→BF : A \to BF:A→B with different images. You can probably think of infinitely many rather quickly. But in fact there are uncountably many, so maybe it's a fun puzzle to see why.
Or, maybe you'll decide that this infinite stuff is not at all what you're interested in!

John Baez said:

I wish you'd give a formal definition of what you mean here by "equally informative". Maybe you have some intuition for it but are still struggling to formalize it. But it's a bit hard for mathematicians to help until you do.

I think this is what I mean (trying to express some intuition precisely): let F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B and G:A→BG: A \to BG:A→B be functors. Then we say that FFF is "at least as informative as GGG about AAA" exactly if there exists a functor H:B→BH: B \to BH:B→B so that G=H∘FG = H \circ FG=H∘F.
The idea is - that whatever GGG is calculating about AAA, that calculation can still be performed using the results of whatever FFF is doing to AAA.
So, two functors FFF and GGG should be equally informative about AAA if there exists H1H_1H1​ and H2H_2H2​ so that G=H2∘FG = H_2 \circ FG=H2​∘F and F=H1∘GF = H_1 \circ GF=H1​∘G.

Oh, wow! The great thing about this definition is that mathematicians will automatically find it familiar and interesting. In this situation we say "GGG factors through FFF". This concept makes sense and is widely studied, not just for categories and functors, but for objects and morphisms in any category.

Given objects AAA and BBB in any category, there's a preorder on the set of morphisms from AAA to BBB such that G≤FG \le FG≤F if GGG factors through FFF. You might enjoy checking that it's a preorder.

It's not a partial ordering because it's not true that

F≤G and G≤F  ⟹  F=GF \le G \text{ and } G \le F \implies F = GF≤G and G≤F⟹F=G
Whenever we have any preorder, we can define F∼GF \sim GF∼G to mean F≤GF \le GF≤G and G≤FG \le FG≤F. Then ∼\sim∼ is an equivalence relation.

In the particular case where the category is Cat, when G≤FG \le FG≤F you're saying "FFF is at least as informative as GGG", and when F∼GF \sim GF∼G you're saying "FFF and GGG are equally informative".
You'll notice I'm telling you the various facts at a fairly high level of generality: "in any category" and "whenever we have any preorder". This is what category theorists like to do.
That way we build up an arsenal of widely useful tools.

Ah, excellent! I will probably indeed enjoy checking that this "informativeness" (or factoring through) gives a preorder.
One reason I care about this is that one could imagine using this concept to put an ordering on some observation-generating part of an imaging system.
Although I guess it's not a very subtle ordering. But perhaps one could do more complex things like considering "informative with respect to observing property PPP".
And then consider a few properties at the same time.
Anyways, thanks!

Before you get too excited it might be good to check that your definition lives up to your expectations. For example, according to your definition, if A is a single point, then all functors A → B are "equally informative". Is that what you expect?

I don't think that's actually true, but it's definitely worth thinking about.

I'm pretty sure that if B is a single point then all functors A → B are "equally informative".

Ok, I see it does indeed form a preorder.
F≤FF \leq FF≤F because F=idB∘FF = id_B \circ FF=idB​∘F
If M≤GM \leq GM≤G and G≤FG \leq FG≤F then we have M=H2∘GM=H_2 \circ GM=H2​∘G and G=H1∘FG = H_1 \circ FG=H1​∘F.
But then M=(H2∘H1)∘FM = (H_2 \circ H_1) \circ FM=(H2​∘H1​)∘F. So M≤FM \leq FM≤F.
Right, the second one is the interesting part of the definition of preorder: the transitive law. The first part, the reflexive law, is kinda obvious.

@John Baez It doesn't matter whether B is a point or not. You can collapse B to a point and then map it to any other point. The relevant triangle commutes because A is just a point and cannot see that you have collapsed B to a point.
You're right. Good point (pardon the pun).

I'm considering the statement "if A is a single point, then all functors A→BA \to BA→B are equally informative".
Let AAA be the category with a single object and its identity morphism.
Let F,GF, GF,G be functors to BBB.
Then FFF is specified by the object it sends the single object of AAA to.
Similarly, GGG is specified by the object it sends the single object of AAA to.
It seems like there exists a functor H:B→BH: B \to BH:B→B that sends one distinguished object to another.
It seems like FFF and GGG are always "equally informative" in this case.

But this makes intuitive sense to me. There isn't a lot to say about AAA besides "it has one object". We can look at ImFIm FImF and ImGIm GImG and see that both FFF and GGG are informing us that AAA has at least one object. Since there isn't anything else to say, it makes sense any observations need to be equally informative.

Well, if you believe the conclusion then I suppose you can go ahead with your definition. Personally, I do not agree – for me it is intuitive that some objects in a category are more informative than others. What is more, which objects are more informative depend on the context.

Zhen Lin Low said:

Well, if you believe the conclusion then I suppose you can go ahead with your definition. Personally, I do not agree – for me it is intuitive that some objects in a category are more informative than others. What is more, which objects are more informative depend on the context.

I think it depends on how broadly one considers the "informativeness" of an object. As you say, it depends on context.

Here I am considering a concept that describes how informative functors are with respect to a fixed object. One could consider a more broad concept that considers how informative objects are (in terms of the informativeness of the functors they support) with respect to a collection of objects, and that should lead to different conclusions.
I suppose a follow up question would be: Does this preoder on functors from AAA to BBB (ordered by "informativeness" or by saying G≤FG \leq FG≤F if GGG factors though FFF) have meets or joins?
Incidentally, I'm pretty sure that G≤FG \leq FG≤F implies that ImGIm GImG is a subcategory of ImFIm FImF.
So this is (if correct) a more concrete way of saying that "FFF observes at least as much about AAA as GGG does"

David Egolf said:

Incidentally, I'm pretty sure that G≤FG \leq FG≤F implies that ImGIm GImG is a subcategory of ImFIm FImF.

I don't think so. For a simple counterexample, take AAA to be (i.e. a category with one object and one morphism), take BBB to be a category with just two objects and their identity morphisms, and let FFF and GGG be the two different functors F,G:A→BF, G: A \to BF,G:A→B.

Zhen Lin showed that if AAA is just a point, and BBB is any category whatsoever, and F,G:A→BF, G : A \to BF,G:A→B are any functors whatsoever, then GGG always factors through FFF... which we're writing as G≤FG \le FG≤F.
In this situation ImFIm FImF and ImGIm GImG can each be any subcategory of BBB that consists of a single object and its identity morphism.
So, typically ImGIm GImG is not a subcategory of ImFIm FImF.

Oh yes, good point.
I'll have to think about this some more.

So, if G≤FG \leq FG≤F, then there exists an HHH so that G=H∘FG = H \circ FG=H∘F.
The idea I'm trying to get at is that HHH should be sending ImFIm FImF to ImGIm GImG.
It probably does.
But that's really different than saying ImF=ImGIm F = Im GImF=ImG.
Maybe you're trying to dream up a preorder on the subcategories of a category.

For context, I was reading a paper on "generalized congruences". I think from that paper that ImFIm FImF is isomorphic to a "quotient category" of AAA induced by FFF, which is called A/∼FA/\sim_FA/∼F​ in that paper. The intuition I'm trying to figure out here is that more informative observations should correspond to observing quotient categories of AAA with less quotienting of things.
Maybe we can say that one subcategory ImGIm GImG is "contained inside of" ImFIm FImF in a general sense if there is a monomorphic functor from ImGIm GImG to ImFIm FImF. So, then, I guess I am hoping that if G≤FG \leq FG≤F then there is a monomorphic functor sending ImGIm GImG to ImFIm FImF.
If this was the case, I think this could indeed end up leading to a preorder on these image subcategories.
Maybe a better way to think about this - Can we quotient Im(F)Im(F)Im(F) to get Im(G)Im(G)Im(G)?
I am tempted to guess that Im(F)/∼H≅Im(G)Im(F)/\sim_H \cong Im(G)Im(F)/∼H​≅Im(G) if G=H∘FG = H \circ FG=H∘F.

For reference, this is the quotienting operation I'm referring to:
quotient

(from "Generalized Congruences — Epimorphisms in Cat")

(Every functor FFF induces a "generalized congruence" defined by identifying objects sent to the same object by FFF, and identifying morphism sequences that are sent to the same morphism by FFF upon composition in the image).

One possible chain of reasoning to relate Im(F)Im(F)Im(F) and Im(G)Im(G)Im(G):
Im(G)=Im(H∘F)≅A/(∼H∘F)≅(A/∼F)/(∼H)≅Im(F)/∼HIm(G) = Im(H \circ F) \cong A/(\sim_{H \circ F}) \cong (A / \sim_F) / (\sim_H) \cong Im(F) /\sim _HIm(G)=Im(H∘F)≅A/(∼H∘F​)≅(A/∼F​)/(∼H​)≅Im(F)/∼H​
However, I need to check that each step of this is actually valid. (Note: I would need to define what I mean by successive quotienting).

One thing that would be helpful to know is this:
Does H(Im(F))=Im(H∘F)H(Im(F)) = Im(H \circ F)H(Im(F))=Im(H∘F) for F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B and H:B→BH: B \to BH:B→B?
(where Im(F)Im(F)Im(F) is the smallest subcategory of BBB containing F(A)F(A)F(A))
Actually, I think we want to know if the smallest subcategory containing H(Im(F))H(Im(F))H(Im(F)) is the same as Im(H∘F)Im(H \circ F)Im(H∘F).
This feels really painfully messy. Maybe there is a better way to think about this.

I think this picture helps;

diagram

The quotient functor Q∼FQ_{\sim_F}Q∼F​​ for F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B sends AAA to A/∼FA/\sim_FA/∼F​.
I believe that A/∼FA/\sim_FA/∼F​ is isomorphic to ImFIm FImF, and so is isomorphic to a subcategory of BBB.
That's why I have drawn monic arrows from those quotient categories into BBB.

The top two cells and the bottom-most cell should commute.
If this is true, then G=H∘F=k∘Q∼(H∘F)=j∘Q∼(H∘i)∘Q∼FG = H \circ F = k \circ Q_{\sim (H \circ F) } = j \circ Q_{\sim (H \circ i)} \circ Q_{\sim F}G=H∘F=k∘Q∼(H∘F)​=j∘Q∼(H∘i)​∘Q∼F​.
I think this means that A/∼H∘FA/{\sim_{H \circ F}}A/∼H∘F​ is mapped into the same subcategory of BBB as is (A∼F)/∼H∘i(A_{\sim F})/\sim_{ H \circ i}(A∼F​)/∼H∘i​
So, I think Im(G)Im(G)Im(G) is isomorphic to Im(F)/∼HIm(F)/\sim_{H}Im(F)/∼H​.

If this is true, this describes how different observations of the same category are related in terms of the smallest subcategory of the image they specify. If FFF is "at least as informative as GGG", then you can compute the subcategory ImGIm GImG by quotienting ImFIm FImF.

As a test, say AAA is a set with two elements viewed as a discrete category, and say BBB is also a set with two elements. Let F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B be a function that sends a1↦b1a_1 \mapsto b_1a1​↦b1​ and a2↦b2a_2 \mapsto b_2a2​↦b2​. Let G:A→BG: A \to BG:A→B be a function that sends both elements to b1b_1b1​. Then G=H∘FG = H \circ FG=H∘F, where H:B→BH: B \to BH:B→B sends both elements to b1b_1b1​.
In this case ImF=BIm F = BImF=B and A/∼F≅AA/\sim_F \cong AA/∼F​≅A. We also have that ImGIm GImG is the subcategory of BBB corresponding to the single element b1b_1b1​ and B/∼GB /\sim_GB/∼G​ is a category with a single object and no non-identity morphisms.

Now, we want to compute Im(F)/∼HIm(F)/\sim_HIm(F)/∼H​. This is a category with a single object and no non-identity morphisms, as HHH sends each element of Im(F)Im(F)Im(F) to the same element. This is indeed isomorphic to Im(G)Im(G)Im(G).
So, at least in this case, we were able to compute ImGIm GImG from ImFIm FImF by doing a quotienting specified by HHH.
I'm not sure I have the willpower to take the sketch based on that picture above and make a proper proof, but this has been interesting anyways.
